item.title: Hello!
item.description:
I love design.

My name is Mark Laughery, and I‚Äôm a UX designer in Tokyo with four years of experience shipping mobile and virtual/augmented reality applications. Having spent most of my professional life in smaller product teams, I‚Äôve had opportunities to sharpen my skills across every end of the UX spectrum. I enjoy all of it, but my path into design was by way of analytics and I‚Äôve grown to recognize the importance of outcome-driven design and product strategy. IDEO‚Äôs ‚ÄúTalk less, do more‚Äù axiom and ‚Äúbuild-to-think‚Äù methodology are core tenets to my approach, and I find my flow in the interaction design, prototyping, and research loop.

I currently work on Indeed‚Äôs employer product. Recent projects include a 2-year vision for the employer mobile app, a complete redesign of the messaging experience, and an internal tool for cross-team knowledge sharing. I work closely with product managers on strategy, user researchers on generative and evaluative research, content strategists on voice, and engineering to ensure quality input and output. I view trust as the central fulcrum to a productive team and seek to promote creativity from all corners of the office (and from users!)

Finally, having worked on teams in Seattle, New York, Austin, Nairobi, Saigon, and Tokyo, I recognize the importance of disparate views, cultures, and life experiences as ingredients to a truly user-centered product. Unless I‚Äôm making a grilled cheese, I try to avoid self-reference and love learning from smart folks around me.

item.title: Indeed
item.description:
My 2019 was spent in Tokyo leading the design of Indeed‚Äôs new employer messaging experience. It‚Äôs a big swing initiative to shift communication away from email and toward real-time chat as part of a wider effort to close the ‚Äúblack hole.‚Äù v1 shipped over the summer and is trending positively across all KPIs. ü§û

Agenda

The following is a high-level overview of the genesis, early development, optimization, and vision for employer messaging. I do my best to supplement the story with relevant visuals and summarize my involvement at each step.

Overview

Business context
  • Black hole (unresponsive employers) has been the biggest job seeker complaint since Indeed‚Äôs inception. Only 9.5% of job applications get a response.
  • We have limited visibility into hiring outcomes. We failed to provide basic functionality and a centralized view of all conversations, which pushed 70% of employer communication out of the platform.
  • Employers using different Indeed products have a disjointed user experience.
  • Templates are a critical part of their messaging workflow and we lacked proper management tools.
Design challenges
  • Make messaging feel lighter and faster by challenging email as the status quo for hiring communication.
  • Balance requirements from over eight teams around the world.
  • Provide sufficient marginal value over email to bring messaging activity back into the platform.
Project details
  • Role: UX lead
  • Team: 2 designers, 1 design technologist, 1 user researcher. Extended team includes 7 developers, 1 PM, and 2 QA.¬†
  • Output: Messaging application on mobile and desktop.¬†
  • Highlights: Working with a brilliant product manager and engineers. Presenting to SLT & 100+ designers across the org. Creating demo that SVP of Product presented at major HR conference. Shipped sweeping redesign of core employer experience that positively impacts tens of millions of people worldwide.
Before & after

Phase 1

Foundational user research & synthesis

Following a 40+ person sprint, we had a full team of engineers in the wings and very little user research to inform our initial product roadmap. As a result, a researcher and I launched a campaign to collect qualitative knowledge every week for two months. Our research included:

  • Synthesis of past research and experimentation in employer communication
  • Digging into interaction logs to get baseline understanding of user behavior (e.g. conversation/message length, message contents, response times)
  • On-site interviews with users
  • Show-me sessions with existing messaging
  • In-app surveys
  • Rapid prototyping and moderated usability testing
Key flows

A key output from this phase were three abstracted flows that aligned job seeker and employer vision

My contribution: Collected and summarized past research. Battled with SQL to get behavioral insight. Attended on-sites and observed show-me sessions. Designed in-app survey.

Maintained high-contact between cross-team stakeholders, design technologist, researcher, PM, and other designers to report out findings and share designs.

Partnered with product management to shape OKRs and MVP specification based on research, technical constraints, and company objectives.

Phase 2

Weekly design, prototyping & usability research sprints

A typical UX has a healthy buffer between design, prototype development, and research. Given our aggressive timeline (we were simultaneously researching and building features for the first couple months üò¨), our transition from foundational user research to prototyping and evaluation was abrupt. We were forced to bundle design and prototyping into one exercise.

I partnered with a design technologist and researcher to generate a high fidelity prototype that was used for stakeholder communication and weekly sessions at the usability lab. Within 7-day sprints, we summarized research findings, adjusted designs, iterated with product stakeholders, communicated changes to developers, revised the prototype, and created research plan.

My contribution: Grand liason. Observed all research sessions and iterated mobile and desktop designs based on observations and internal product feedback. Produced extensive behavioral specifications to accompany prototype that shared referenced with developer team.

The battleground, aka UX lab

Phase 3

Ongoing optimization & experimentation

Following launch and stabilization, I spent lunches sitting in a room with my PM watching session recordings (actual users in prod), and categorizing feedback from our monthly pulse survey. We took observed issues back to the team to find solutions. After quick brainstorming sessions, winning concepts were pulled into the research prototype and gut-checked on usertesting.com. This improvement process was powerful in ensuring seamless UX and effectively reduced CS tickets.

Hotjar recording + categorized feedback from our monthly pulse survey

My contribution: Categorized thousands of lines of survey results. Led a brainstorming session with wider team. Worked with design technologist and user researcher to run usertesting studies. Created improvement tickets for developers.

Phase 4

Post-MVP: Shaping¬†roadmap

Following the initial mayhem, we fell back into our regular cadence of research and delivery. The foundation was set, we had bandwidth, and were far enough ahead of our engineering roadmap to lift our heads and think about our vision. A few concepts we researched:

Voice introductions

Empowering job seekers to send the first message, while giving employers a more compelling cover letter replacement.

Framework for ‚Äòenriched messaging‚Äô

Hybrid graphical and text conversation interface. Important guidelines for other teams creating messaging plugins.

Template management & functional placeholders

We eventually got our ducks in a row, traveled to Austin, Seattle, and San Francisco, and codified our vision.

Prioritization grid

Timeline

Company-wide presentation

Sharing messaging vision and progress with SLT and wider UX org (100+ designers).

SVP of Product presents vision in keynote at Indeed Interactive

Indeed's SVP of Product asked us to produce a demo for his keynote at Indeed Interactive conference in 2019. Here's the result:

In the end we worked with a design technologist to build this whole flow and they successfully demoed it live!

item.title: Pyrus
item.description:
I spent two years working with doctors in Seattle and Canada to improve MRI/CT imaging. We focused on VR software for perioperative education and AR-based navigation for minimally-invasive procedures.

Key contributions
  • Created business plan and prototype to secure initial grant
  • Developed model management app in React.js
  • Built VR interface in Unity
  • Designed & researched first-of-its-kind VR input model, ‚ÄòTouch Motion,‚Äô that combines Oculus Touch and Leap Motion
  • Created mobile app that used sockets to connect to a HoloLens and function as a input device
  • Led frequent contextual inquiry and usability analyses with doctors
Key design challenges
  • Maintaining a user-centered approach in a highly regulated, complex technical environment with a broad constituency
  • Discovery & learning: Building relationships with hospitals and practitioners to establish consistent feedback loop
  • Control in VR: Identifying ideal input model that's learnable, precise, and natural
  • Tool selection menu: How do users move between different fuctions in VR?
  • Model managament: Streamlining the process of importing DICOM images from workstations and getting them into our VR environment
  • Pivoting into AR
Challenge 1

Maintaining a user-centered approach in a highly regulated, complex technical environment with a broad constituency

Solution 1: Up-front due diligence

Abstracted product and business planning helped identify tertiary audiences, contextual/regulatory constraints, and aligned all members of the team around key milestones and deliverables. In the face of enigmatic requirements, perpetual famine, and complex healthcare go-to-market, up-front planning helped clarify milestones, recognize wider market trends, and navigate the regulatory labrynth.

Solution: Problem mapping

Challenge Outcome
Complex service environment Clarity and scope of problem
Diverse constituency Understanding of disparate needs and influences
Many potential use cases Artifact for use in interviews
Challenge 2

Discovery & learning: Building relationships with hospitals and practitioners to establish consistent feedback loop

Solution: Rolling play-pen

Anyone who's experimented with VR is familiar with the rats nest of sensors and cables. We spent half the week outside of the office (with a scooter as our primary mode of transportation!) and our caravan was branded the "rolling play-pen." Though we laughed at the time, I now realize it was this tactic that guaranteed our success.

Challenge 3

Control in VR: Identifying ideal input model that‚Äôs learnable, precise, and natural

Our biggest design challenge was figuring out how to accomodate ‚Äònatural‚Äô gestures with efficient, precise, and predictable input. Efficiency is critical for doctors and they had a low threshold for onboarding and recall. This was the most important part of our user experience and where we invested the most in research. The following highlights key steps in our investigation.

Experiment 1: Google Cardboard

Benefits Drawbacks
Mobile; lightweight & accessible Way too limited (just gaze and one button)
¬† Laggy with big models
Experiment 2: DK2 + Leap Motion

Benefits Drawbacks
Hardware light (no controller to learn) Tracking: Unpredictable & imprecise
Basic controls are intuitive IR silhouette intersection
Experiment 3: Xbox controller

Benefits Drawbacks
Predictable & Comforable Difficult to extract substructures
Lots of input options Doctors hated it; felt like gaming.
Experiment 4: Perception Neuron

Benefits Drawbacks
Performant & Precise tracking Way too much configuration
¬† Clunky, fragile hardware
Experiment 5: Touch motion ‚ù§Ô∏è
Challenge 4

Action menu with touch motion

Touch motion hit the sweet spot between precision and intuition. Our next challenge was to create an efficient system for switching between modes and tools.

v1: Pane

Users summoned a menu with the controller and selected actions with their free hand. This was easy to create using Unity Canvas and Leap Motion button elements, but it wasn't scalable and prone to selection error.

v2: Radial menu
Challenge Outcome
Hiding functionality behind buttons resulted in recall challenge Faster and easily memorized menu selection flow
Two-handed menus are slow and require dexterity Fewer human factors issues
MORE new user errors

item.title: Ajua
item.description:
Ajua is a research technology company out of MIT that connects health researchers and businesses with populations in hard-to-reach areas using SMS. After spending a summer in Nairobi, I continued to provide design and front-end development support during my second year of grad school.

The techincal expectations were much greater than anticipated, so I spent the first month focused on research and design, while spending evenings studying front-end languages, frameworks, and best practices. In the second half of my internship I was spending most of my time on interface development and battling d3.

I ultimately worked on a product called Consumer Wallet that measured Kenya‚Äôs cash-based economy in real time that was covered in Forbes, 2017.
